title: The US vetoes UN Security Council resolution calling for immediate ceasefire in Gaza
description: Friday's resolution, supported by nearly all Security Council members and many other nations, urged an instant cease-fire in Gaza, where Palestinian civilians are enduring what the UN chief describes as a 'humanitarian nightmare.'

title: US approves breakthrough sickle cell therapy that uses gene-editing tool
description: US regulators on Friday approved two gene therapies for sickle cell disease that doctors hope can cure the painful, inherited blood disorder that afflicts mostly Black people in the US.

title: Six French teenagers convicted over their roles in killing of teacher
description: A French juvenile court handed suspended sentences to six teenagers for their  involvement in the killing of  Samuel Paty, beheaded by an Islamic extremist after he showed caricatures of Muhammad to his class for a debate on freedom of expression.

title: Israel documents sexual violence committed during Hamas attack
description: Since October 7, women have stepped forward to share their stories, but the chaotic nature of the massacre makes the investigation of sexual crimes difficult.

title: One in six Swiss MPs is a farmer
description: There may be fewer and fewer farmers in the country, but they are now the best-represented profession in the new Swiss parliament.

title: ICC prosecutor's cautious approach to Israel and Gaza under scrutiny
description: The October 7 attack by Hamas and the Israeli bombings in Gaza have led the International Criminal Court Prosecutor Karim Khan to give priority to the Israeli-Palestinian issue. This investigation is being closely monitored by states and NGOs.

title: Israel forces Gazans into new exodus toward Rafah: 'Where do they want us to move to?'
description: With makeshift shelters erected not far from the Egyptian border, most of those fleeing have already been displaced several times since the start of the war.

title: Le Pen, her party, and 26 people will be tried over fake European Parliament jobs
description: Marine Le Pen and her party are charged with embezzlement of public funds and collusion, accused of using EU funds to pay for party staff. The trial is scheduled to take place from March to November 2024.

title: A culpable apathy to the 'normalization' of Le Pen's Rassemblement National
description: For the first time, 43% of French people surveyed think that the Rassemblement National, a party with xenophobic and authoritarian aims, is capable of participating in government. Hardly anyone among the political and social forces is bothering to expose its inconsistencies and highlight the dangerous nature of its program.

title: Macron asks to transform the way research is organized in France
description: Emmanuel Macron announced the creation of a 'presidential council' to advise him on the progress of science, and has given research organizations and universities 18 months to 'restore clarity' in the war France's scientific community is organized.

title: Putin announces he will run for fifth term in 2024 presidential election
description: Vladimir Putin, 71, has led Russia since the turn of the century, winning four presidential terms with an interlude as prime minister. Unlikely to be seriously challenged, Putin could stay in power until at least 2036, following his 2020 constitutional reform.

title: Spanish economy minister to head European Investment Bank
description: Nadia Calvino beat out EU Commissioner Margarethe Vestager to head the world's biggest multilateral public lender, whose decisions form the crux of several major EU debates, including funding war-torn Ukraine, the green transition and nuclear power.

title: Macron announces creation of Notre-Dame museum and contest to restore stained glass
description: President Emmanuel Macron visited the Parisian cathedral, one year ahead of its scheduled reopening.

title: What is the Martel Division, the neonazi group banned by the French government?
description: This radical far-right group, founded in 2022, was dissolved by the Council of Ministers on December 6. It had planned violent actions against people of North African descent, and several of its militants were involved in recent street clashes.

title: Pledging 'retribution,' Trump fuels fears for rule of law
description: The former president, the favorite for the Republican nomination, is putting forward his proposals for a second term. But even some of his fellow conservatives are worried about his vengeful rhetoric.

title: Hanukkah ceremony at Elysée sparks secularism backlash against Macron
description: After the chief rabbi of France lit a Hannukah candle in Emmanuel Macron's company at the presidential palace, all the opposition parties have criticized a breach of French secularism, as has the head of the Representative Council of French Jewish Institutions.

title: Turkey and Greece open 'new, calmer chapter' in tumultuous relationship
description: The Turkish president, visiting Athens for the first time in seven years, signed a 'declaration of friendship and good-neighborly relations' with the Greek prime minister, testifying to their desire to ease the heightened tensions of recent years.

title: Kazakhstan buys ArcelorMittal subsidiary after mining accidents
description: The mineral-rich Central Asian country announced the $286 million deal to buy ArcelorMittal's Temirtau subsidiary, after the company was asked to leave Kazakhstan in October after a string of accidents in the company's mines claimed over 50 lives.

title: Cambodia displaces villagers from Angkor Wat
description: The Cambodian PM cited UNESCO World Heritage Site 'conditions' behind the relocations. UNESCO has said they 'never requested' this program, which Amnesty International has denounced as 'forced evictions.'

title: Taiwan detects Chinese balloon and aircraft in strait
description: In an incident reminiscent of the February 'Chinese spy balloon' event in the US, Taiwan's defense ministry announced that 1 balloon, 26 aircraft and 10 Chinese ships were detected in the Taiwan Strait, with some crossing the sensitive median line.

title: From Mexico's Sinaloa to the skyscrapers of Dubai, the art of laundering fentanyl money
description: Bertrand Monnet, a business professor and a specialist in crime economics, conducted a field study into the trafficking of this devastating opioid. He explains how the Mexican Sinaloa cartel launders its enormous profits in the emirate.

title: 'Picassomania' reduces art to its cult of great men
description: The hyper-concentration of museums' offerings on a few well-known names, for the sake of profitability, is to the detriment of more experimental programming, and therefore of current creative artwork.

title: Hunter Biden indicted on tax evasion charges
description: Hunter Biden was indicted on nine tax charges in California on Thursday as a special counsel investigation into the business dealings of President Joe Biden's son intensifies against the backdrop of the looming 2024 election.

title: Greece: The legalization of same-sex marriage remains divisive
description: Conservative Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis intends to introduce legislation in the near future, but the project is dividing his party and society.

title: US lawmakers launch probe into anti-Semitism at top universities
description: The investigation comes after the presidents of Harvard, the University of PenUniversity of Pennsylvania and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology received criticism over their testimony Tuesday on rising anti-Semitism on campus.
